Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 51291-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
June 2018 
Strengthening Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Knowledge Partnerships and Research Network in 
Asia and the Pacific 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
ADB  – Asian Development Bank
ADBI  – Asian Development Bank Institute
APRU  – Association of Pacific Rim Universities
ASEAN  – Association of Southeast Asian Nations
ATTN  – ADB–Asian Think Tanks Network
ERCD  – Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department
RCI  – regional cooperation and integration
TA  – technical assistance
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) 
Director  Cyn-Young Park, Regional Cooperation and Integration Division, ERCD

Aleli Rosario, Senior Economics Officer, ERCD 
Peter Rosenkranz, Economist, ERCD 
Pia Tenchavez, Senior Operations Assistant, ERCD

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I. INTRODUCTION
1. The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  strengthen  knowledge
partnerships on emerging themes relevant to regional cooperation and integration (RCI) by
encouraging and supporting research collaboration among policy research institutions in Asia and
the Pacific. It will also support research networks by organizing technical workshops and high-
level policy dialogues to produce policy papers and a book and/or report volume for policy makers
in the region.
2. The TA is included in the 2018 annual work program for the Economic Research and
Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to build policy
research capacity in institutions in developing member countries.1 The TA objectives are also
linked to the Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020, which
focuses on (i) collective action for multicountry mechanisms promoting trade, investment, and
labor mobility; (ii) regional public health, climate change, and disaster risk mitigation; and (iii)
strong cooperation mechanisms requiring collective action.2
II. ISSUES
3. Regional integration has played a pivotal role economic and social development in Asia
and the Pacific by expanding markets and boosting productivity. It also helps the development
process become more inclusive, bringing with it important noneconomic benefits of security and
political stability. The European Union is an example of a deeply interconnected region that has
gained considerable efficiency through trading and the sharing of natural and human resources.
4. To continue taking advantage of the benefits of regional integration, policy makers must
cooperate closely on the economic and related development agendas that are of mutual interest
to countries in Asia and the Pacific. These agendas include economic issues such as trade and
regional value chains, social issues such as human capital and inclusive growth, environmental
concerns, and calls for regional actions that go beyond domestic or bilateral remedies.
5. Knowledge management helps policy makers respond to challenges and opportunities by
generating and disseminating targeted research. Regional research collaboration among groups
of experts who stay informed about the context, priorities, constraints, and challenges of regional
and national policies is key to generating policy-relevant knowledge on RCI. Collaboration can
consist of jointly identifying key policy agenda and research questions; sharing data, research
methods,  and  techniques  to  conduct  proposed  research;  and  drafting  and  adopting  policy
recommendations  based  on  research  outcomes.  Collaboration  also  generates  synergies  in
making research outcomes broadly relevant, actionable, and effective. Knowledge management,
in the context of the RCI agenda, will help individual countries identify regional solutions to region-
wide concerns.
6. Although ADB’s research efforts and publication of flagship reports and other research
initiatives have increased the volume of literature on issues such as trade and value chains, the
number and the quality of RCI research collaborations are insufficient in other areas, such as the
following:
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 April 2018. 
2  ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

2 
(i)  Aging, demographic change, technology, and labor mobility. Populations are 
aging and workforces are shrinking in many countries, including in emerging 
economies. These demographic changes will have an impact on labor markets and 
overall patterns of economic structure and growth, and on the ways in which labor 
moves across regional borders. Technology plays an increasing role in boosting 
the productivity of workers, including the elderly. Given diverse demographic 
profiles, regional efforts by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) 
to plan human capital development and facilitate cross-border labor mobility will 
benefit the region. However, such efforts may require inputs from regional experts 
across  multiple  disciplines,  including  demography,  public  finance,  and  labor 
economics. To date, ADB’s research on aging and demographic changes has 
focused on aging and the social security and/or care system or economic growth 
in  general  but  none  has  approached  the  issue  from  the  angle  of  regional 
collaboration.3 
(ii)  Disaster risk reduction frameworks. While Asia and the Pacific is increasingly 
experiencing the impact of climate change and recurring natural disasters, the 
burden for coping and rebuilding falls mostly on small and vulnerable economies. 
The need to strengthen regional cooperation and the mechanism for sharing 
disaster risks is urgent. Innovative ways to mitigate risk have already emerged, 
such as disaster risk financing and insurance, which ADB and the World Bank are 
implementing in selected countries. The Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk 
Reduction, 2015–2030 recognizes the significant role of regional cooperation in 
addressing  the  increasing  threat  of  disasters.4 The  Asia  Regional  Plan  for 
Implementation of the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, 2015–2030 
provides broad policy direction, a long-term plan, and a 2-year action plan for 
regional cooperation and collaboration on building risk resilience.5 A study can look 
at how regional cooperation can help develop the region's resilience to disasters 
by  (a)  better  understanding,  assessing,  and  monitoring  disaster  risk;  (b) 
strengthening disaster risk governance; and (c) improving coordination across 
relevant institutions, sectors, and countries. 
 
7.  Several reasons may explain why collaborative research on these topics has not taken 
place. First, a country’s incentive to invest in regional cooperation and RCI knowledge can be 
stifled by the high cost of conducting the research on its own when the results could benefit other 
nations, especially those at its border. Second, since Asia and the Pacific consists of countries 
with diverse economic and social profiles, collaborative research requires significant technical 
expertise and in-depth knowledge of the region and its countries. This is especially true if the 
issue at stake has broad social and cultural implications. Third, implementation of joint research 
typically requires some type of preexisting relationships and partnerships, which are scarce in the 
research topics highlighted in para. 6 (i)–(ii). Lastly, the technical capacity of research institutions 
in the region varies substantially, with some such institutions in developing economies lacking the 
resources to conduct joint RCI research. As a result, efforts to conduct research that identifies 
good practices and innovative regional solutions to RCI themes tend to be carried out in a stand-
alone or fragmented manner. Where collaboration exists, it tends to focus on sharing country-
specific analysis of a common topic but falls short of joint research that aims to provide regional 
                                                
3  ADB. 2017. Asian Development Outlook 2017: Transcending the Middle-Income Challenge. Manila; and D. Park, S. 
Lee, and A. Mason, eds. 2012. Aging, Economic Growth, and Old-Age Security in Asia. Manila: ADB; Cheltenham, 
Gloucestershire, United Kingdom and Northampton, Massachusetts: Edward Elgar Publishing. 
4  United Nations. 2015. Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, 2015–2030. Geneva. 
5  United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction. 2016. Asia Regional Plan for Implementation of the Sendai 
Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, 2015–2030. Geneva.

3 
solutions  and  recommendations  on  the  regional  agenda.  The  situation  requires  proactive 
promotion of RCI-themed research partnerships across Asia and the Pacific. 
 
8.  ADB  is  addressing  the  challenge  by  building  general  networking  platforms  among 
research institutions. Through the implementation of TA for the Provision of Knowledge Products 
and Services to Developing Member Countries through Systematic Knowledge Sharing, ADB 
helped  establish  the  ADB–Asian  Think  Tanks  Network  (ATTN),  a  networking  platform  for 
government-affiliated think tanks in Asia and the Pacific.6 Similarly, the Asian Development Bank 
Institute (ADBI), in partnership with the Think Tanks and Civil Society Program of the University 
of Pennsylvania, hosts the Asia Think Tanks Secretariat, organizes the annual Asia Think Tank 
Summit, and maintains the Think Asia portal that serves more than 100 institutions. As the 
network of think tanks strengthened, some think tanks expressed desire to do joint research work 
with ADB on topics of mutual interest and to play a policy advisory role in the region. 
 
9.  A few initiatives to promote research on the regional agenda by forging collaboration 
among research institutions exist, but can be strengthened. Some institutions with regional 
presence have expressed interest for such an endeavor, including ADBI and the Association of 
Pacific Rim Universities (APRU), which has a membership of 45 universities. The resulting policy-
relevant studies would benefit developing member countries, policy makers, and ADB’s regional 
departments, as they could provide basis for regional solutions to cross-border issues. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: policy makers are provided with enhanced 
knowledge on emerging themes on RCI (footnote 2). Improved cooperation among research 
institutions helps enhance the quality and quantity of knowledge, which creates more and better-
informed policy makers and development practitioners who will prepare regional responses to 
RCI challenges. 
 
11.  The TA will have the following outcome: knowledge collaboration on selected RCI themes 
among policy research institutions in ADB member countries strengthened.7 Research institutions 
in Asia and the Pacific are expected to build networks and forge partnerships among themselves 
by taking part in joint RCI research, which offers opportunities to interact and share research 
ideas, progress, and outcomes. These institutions will also gain experience in implementing 
regional collaborative research whose outputs will support a collective response to cross-border 
issues. Through policy dialogues under this TA, institutions not directly involved in research may 
also benefit from stronger research capacities and networks. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Collaborative regional cooperation and integration research conducted. 
The TA will facilitate the inception and implementation of two joint research initiatives on RCI 
themes in collaboration with policy research institutions in the region. Each initiative will produce 
several papers analyzing the choice of RCI theme, with an aim to identify regional solutions and 
                                                
6  ADB. Regional: Provision of Knowledge Products and Services to Developing Member Countries through Systematic 
Knowledge  Sharing.  https://www.adb.org/projects/46244-001/main;  and  ADB–Asian  Think  Tanks  Network. 
http://www.adb-asianthinktanks.org. The TA team held five regional forums that provided a networking platform for 
think tanks and opportunities to share knowledge on innovation, inclusive growth, urban planning, and infrastructure. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
policy options. ADB and the APRU have identified two themes for research collaboration: (i) aging, 
demographic changes, and labor mobility; and (ii) disaster risk-sharing mechanisms. The project 
team  will  identify  the  details  of  the  research  themes  and  potential  partner  institutions  in 
consultation with the organizations supporting regional research platforms, including the APRU 
and ADBI, prioritizing the issues discussed in regional forums such as ASEAN and Asia-Pacific 
Economic  Cooperation.8 It  will  hold  one  inception  workshop  per  theme  for  key  research 
institutions  to  initiate  discussions  that  would  generate  innovative  research  concepts  and 
methodologies that would take full advantage of the collaborators’ expertise. For this workshop, 
the project team will launch an open call for submissions of innovative research from scholars. 
ADB will lead a group of experts in conducting an anonymous review to select papers for 
presentation. 
 
13.  The  project  team  is  anticipating  carrying  out  a  typical  joint  research  initiative  in 
collaboration with multiple institutions in the region.9 Participating research institutions can be 
government think tanks, public or private universities, or other research institutions that conduct 
policy-relevant social and economic development research and have a proven track record of 
research activities in identified themes. ERCD and its Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Division will also be part of the research team. 
 
14.  Output  2:  Developing  member  country  researchers  actively  participated  and 
deepened knowledge on the research themes. Technical workshops will allow research 
progress and draft research papers to be presented and evaluated by research project members 
and invited external experts, where needed. In addition, the project team will hold two high-level 
policy forums to disseminate research findings and policy recommendations. It will collaborate 
with the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation and ASEAN secretariats, Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Institute, and other similar regional bodies in organizing dialogues to 
maximize exposure and participation. The project team will make an effort to engage and 
encourage ATTN members to participate in research. 
 
15.  Output 3: Policy papers and book and/or report volume printed and disseminated. 
Research papers and policy recommendations will be published as policy briefs and as an 
electronic book and/or report. Electronic publication will be the primary channel of dissemination, 
but some papers may be printed for targeted policy makers and institutions and disseminated 
based on demand. These documents will be disseminated to a wider regional audience through 
outreach activities (at least one event per publication) and social media and will be made available 
through the websites of ADB, ADBI, APRU, and other participating research institutions. The 
project team will maintain the ATTN website and use it as a platform for dissemination.10 Other 
dissemination activities will be tied to related ADB and ERCD events. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA budget is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
                                                
8  The project team may consider running two parallel research initiatives simultaneously to maximize efforts to identify 
innovative research and policy solutions. 
9  The project team could explore knowledge partnerships that are consistent with ADB’s staff instructions (ADB. 2017. 
Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance Operations. 
Compendium of Staff Instructions. Manila) if, in the process of implementation, such an arrangement would be more 
appropriate. 
10 The project team will enhance and update ATTN’s existing website.

5 
D. Implementation Arrangements
17. ADB will administer the TA. ERCD will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants;
organize workshops; and evaluate the accomplishment of outputs. On selected topics, ERCD will
provide staff to act as resource persons for the workshops. It will collaborate with research
institutions in the region for joint research work in the chosen areas.
18. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  July 2018–June 2020 
Executing agency  ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
ICS  International (7 person-months)  $96,000 
ICS  National (40 person-months)  $106,000 
ICS (if with  International and national resource  $30,000 
honoraria)  persons (1 person-month total) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ICS = individual consultant selection, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
19. Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions
and/or staff instructions.11 ADB will consider lump-sum payments and output-based contracts for
consulting  services.  Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  follow  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
20. Social media and website. The project team will update and maintain the existing ATTN
website regularly.12 Before project closing, it will explore other sources of financing for website
maintenance if there is strong demand for the website’s continued existence.
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Regional Cooperation and Integration Knowledge Partnerships and Research 
Network in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
12 The project team will collaborate with the Office of Information Systems and Technology to ensure that proper ADB 
information technology security controls are implemented.

Key Activities with Milestones

2nd theme: January 2019)

research themes

metadata.Subject:
The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen knowledge partnerships on emerging themes relevant to regional cooperation and integration (RCI) by encouraging and supporting research collaboration among policy research institutions in Asia and
the Pacific.
metadata.Title: Strengthening Regional Cooperation and Integration Knowledge Partnerships and Research Network in Asia and the Pacific: Technical Assistance Report

ABBREVIATIONS 
ADB  – Asian Development Bank
ADBI  – Asian Development Bank Institute
APRU  – Association of Pacific Rim Universities
ASEAN  – Association of Southeast Asian Nations
ATTN  – ADB–Asian Think Tanks Network
ERCD  – Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department
RCI  – regional cooperation and integration
TA  – technical assistance
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) 
Director  Cyn-Young Park, Regional Cooperation and Integration Division, ERCD 
Team leader  Aiko Kikkawa Takenaka, Economist, ERCD 
Team member  Carol Ongchangco, Operations Coordinator, ERCD 
Aleli Rosario, Senior Economics Officer, ERCD

territory or area.
